questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for chronic kidney disease?

choices.text: Large for gestational age at birth

questions.solution:
Small for gestational age (SGA) at birth is a risk factor for chronic kidney disease (CKD), not LGA.

Important risk factors for CKD or chronic renal failure are:

  • SGA
  • Childhood obesity
  • Hypertension
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Autoimmune disease
  • Family history of kidney disease
  • Previous episode of acute kidney injury
  • Structural abnormalities of the urinary tract
  • Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease

questions.text: What is the most common cause of chronic kidney disease?
questions.solution:
Diabetic nephropathy is the most common cause of chronic kidney disease (CKD).

The leading causes of CKD in decreasing order of frequency are as follows: 

  • Diabetic nephropathy  
  • Glomerulonephritis 
  • Hypertension-associated CKD  
  • ADPKD (Adult or autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease)

questions.text: Patients with which of the following conditions are unlikely to develop chronic renal failure?
questions.solution: Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is least likely to cause chronic renal failure. It is a rapidly progressive condition and a cause of acute renal failure.

questions.text: Which of the following parameters are used in the staging of chronic kidney disease?
questions.solution:
Stages of chronic kidney disease (CKD) are stratified by estimated GFR (eGFR) and degree of albuminuria in order to predict the risk of progression of CKD. Serum creatinine is not directly used in the staging of chronic kidney disease.

questions.text: In patients with chronic kidney disease, at which stage do the complications of kidney failure start appearing?
questions.solution:
The features of kidney failure become prominent as the GFR progressively declines to stages 3 and 4. The following complications occur as a result of loss of kidney function:

  • Volume overload
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Metabolic acidosis
  • Hyperphosphatemia
  • Mineral and bone disorders
  • Hypertension
  • Anemia
  • Dyslipidemia

questions.text: A 66-year-old woman is being evaluated for new-onset uremic encephalopathy. What is her GFR likely to be?
questions.solution:
Clinical features of uremia start to appear in patients with GFR < 15 mL/min/1.73 m2 or end-stage renal disease (ESRD). By this stage, renal clearance is severely impaired and the accumulation of uremic toxins leads to several complications including:

  • Uremic encephalopathy
  • Pruritus
  • Malnutrition
  • Anorexia, nausea, fatigue
  • Platelet dysfunction
  • Sexual dysfunction
  • Pericarditis, pleuritis
  • Peripheral neuropathy

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about uremic syndrome?

choices.text: It occurs due to accumulation of toxins
There is loss of kidney function and hormone regulation
Can be eliminated by removing urea through intensive dialysis

questions.solution:
Uremic syndrome cannot be eliminated by removing urea alone. It is a complex condition occurring due to the accumulation of multiple toxins.

The pathophysiology of uremic syndrome involves the following:

  • Accumulation of toxins (uremia) - urea, creatinine, other products of protein metabolism like urates, hippurates, polyamines, indoles.
  • Loss of kidney function leading to fluid and electrolyte imbalance and hormone dysregulation.
  • Progressive systemic inflammation with vascular and nutritional impairment.

Clinical features secondary to loss of kidney function tend to develop in parallel with declining GFR. However the features of uremia and, hence, uremic syndrome, usually occur only in stage 5 or ESRD.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with CKD has been on dialysis for 3 months. He now presents with intense body pains and muscle pain. He suffered from 2 fractures over the last 2 months.  On evaluation, he was found to have decreased PTH levels and normal calcium levels. He has been regularly taking oral vitamin D and calcium tablets. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario in a CKD patient is suggestive of adynamic bone disease.

In CKD, metabolic bone disorders (renal osteodystrophy) can be of three types:

High bone turnover

Decreased calcium leads to a mild increase in PTH, which stimulates osteoblasts. Thus the bone volume is maintained.

High vitamin D  decreases PTH levels, which leads to decreased bone volume.

Mineralization is defective because of aluminium, which comes from dialysis.

Treatment:

questions.text: A middle-aged woman with chronic kidney disease presents to the OPD  with exercise intolerance, fatigue, and shortness of breath.  On examination, she is found to have severe pallor.  Which of the following is least likely to be a cause for these findings?
questions.solution:
Sickle cell anemia is not a feature of chronic kidney disease (CKD).

Common causes of anemia in CKD include:

  • Erythropoietin deficiency
  • Diminished red blood cell survival
  • Bleeding diathesis
  • Iron deficiency
  • Vitamin B12 and folate deficiency
  • Hyperparathyroidism (due to bone marrow fibrosis)
  • Hemoglobinopathy

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in patients with chronic renal failure?
questions.solution:
Hyperthyroidism is not a feature of chronic renal failure.

Option A: Peripheral neuropathy can occur secondary to uremia.

Options C and D: In chronic renal failure, calcitriol (vitamin D3) production is decreased, leading to metabolic bone disease, which in turn leads to low serum calcium levels, secondary hyperparathyroidism, and osteomalacia.

questions.text: What is the most common neurological disorder seen in patients with CKD?
questions.solution:
The most common neurological disorder seen in patients with CKD is peripheral neuropathy.

The various neuromuscular manifestations of CKD include:

  • Memory and concentration impairment
  • Dialysis dementia - due to aluminum intoxication
  • Restless leg syndrome
  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Hiccups
  • Cramps
  • Uremic encephalopathy
    • Confusion and lethargy
    • Tremors
    • Myoclonus
    • Asterixis
    • Seizures
    • Coma

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman goes to her family doctor as she is unable to fall asleep at night. She complains of tingling and crawling sensations over her legs at night. She also feels a strong urge to move her legs, which relieves the symptoms for a while. Which of the following is incorrect about this condition?

choices.text: Most common cause is chronic kidney disease
Most common movement disorder in pregnancy

questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of restless legs syndrome (RLS) or Willis-Ekbom disease. Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is not the most common cause of this condition.   

RLS is a neurological sleep disorder that can be primary or secondary. The primary form is more common. It shows autosomal dominant inheritance in most cases, but can be idiopathic. Secondary RLS is associated with the following:

  • Iron deficiency 
  • Pregnancy - most common movement disorder
  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • CKD
  • Parkinson's disease
  • Multiple sclerosis

It is characterized by an uncontrollable, restless urge to move the legs. It tends to worsen during periods of inactivity and at evening or night. It is accompanied by crawling, tingling or burning sensations. These symptoms show partial or complete improvement with movement. This cycle may continue for a while and result in insomnia.

Primary RLS is managed by improving sleep hygiene and dopamine agonists (pramipexole or ropinirole) if symptoms persist. Iron supplements can also be given. In secondary RLS, the underlying cause must be treated.

questions.text: What is the most likely cause of convulsions in a patient with CKD?
questions.solution: The most likely cause of convulsions in a patient with CKD is water intoxication. Volume overload in these patients as well as damage to the blood-brain barrier by uremic toxins causes cerebral edema and seizures.

questions.text: What is most common cause of mortality in patients with chronic kidney disease?
questions.solution: Cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in patients at every stage of CKD.

questions.text: Which of the following would be elevated in patients with chronic kidney disease?
questions.solution:
Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is associated with elevated levels of fibrinogen. 

CKD is a pro-inflammatory state characterized by altered levels of acute-phase reactants (APR) 

  • Elevated levels of positive APR like CRP and fibrinogen (associated with high ESR).
  • Reduced levels of negative APR like albumin and fetuin.

questions.text: What is the predominant electrolyte abnormality seen in patients with advanced CKD?
questions.solution:
High anion gap metabolic acidosis is the predominant electrolyte abnormality in a patient with advanced CKD. In advanced CKD, impaired renal functioning causes decreased urinary excretion of acids. These retained organic acids result in a high anion gap.

In early CKD, potassium retention is associated with bicarbonate loss. This gives rise to hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis with a normal anion gap in early CKD.

The following electrolyte abnormalities are seen in CKD:

  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hyperphosphatemia
  • Hyperuricemia
  • Hypermagnesemia

Hypokalemia is uncommon in CKD and usually reflects markedly reduced dietary potassium intake, especially in association with excessive diuretic therapy or concurrent GI losses.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most life-threatening manifestation of CKD?
questions.solution:
Of the given options, hyperkalemia is the most life-threatening complication of chronic kidney disease (CKD) as it can result in cardiac arrhythmias and sudden death.

CKD is staged based on declining glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and albuminuria. The various clinical manifestations occur due to loss of kidney function and accumulation of various uremic toxins (urea, creatinine, and other products of protein metabolism).

Complications of declining kidney function include:

  • Volume overload
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Metabolic acidosis
  • Hyperphosphatemia
  • Mineral and bone disorders
  • Hypertension
  • Anemia
  • Dyslipidemia

questions.text: Patients with CKD have increased levels of all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Serum estrogen levels are low in CKD patients. This leads to menstrual abnormalities and infertility. 

Option A: Plasma levels of insulin are elevated in CKD patients due to impaired clearance by the affected kidneys. Hence, insulin dose must be reduced in these patients.

Option B: Elevated parathyroid hormone levels in CKD are secondary to derangements in the homeostasis of calcium, phosphate, and vitamin D.

Option D: FGF-23 (fibroblast growth factor) is part of a family of phosphatonins that promotes renal phosphate excretion. The levels of this hormone increase early in the course of CKD.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency with chest pain that is radiating to his shoulder, shortness of breath, and diaphoresis. He is a known case of chronic kidney disease. Which of the following investigations is best for diagnosis?

choices.text: Troponin levels on admission and 1 hour later
Troponin and CK-MB levels at admission

questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of acute myocardial infarction (MI) in a patient with chronic kidney disease (CKD). A serial rise in cardiac troponin levels over 3-6 hours following presentation is needed to make a diagnosis. An interval of 1-hour is not considered sufficient. 

Minor chronic elevations in serum troponins are commonly observed in patients with CKD even in the absence of cardiovascular disease. Hence, a single elevated troponin value in such patients cannot be used to diagnose MI. 

CK-MB is far less sensitive and specific than troponins. Hence, it is not preferred.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most sensitive test to detect early diabetic nephropathy in a patient?
questions.solution:
Microalbuminuria is the most sensitive and earliest finding of diabetic nephropathy. It refers to urine albumin of 30–300 mg/24-hour urine.  It is seen in the stage of incipient diabetic kidney disease. 

However, microalbuminuria is a very variable finding and is not required to diagnose nephropathy. Non-albuminuric diabetic nephropathy may occur in some patients and regression of albuminuria may be seen in type 1 diabetics.

Diabetic nephropathy can be diagnosed if the following are satisfied: 

  • Reduced GFR (< 60 mL/min/1.73 m2) with or without persistent albuminuria (> 30 mg/day or urine PCR > 30 mg/g)
  • Long duration of diabetes or established diabetic retinopathy
  • Other etiologies are ruled out

questions.text: A patient with chronic kidney disease is found to have normal-sized kidneys on ultrasonography. Which of the following diagnoses is least likely?
questions.solution:
Hypertensive nephropathy is unlikely in this patient as it usually presents with shrunken kidneys.

Longstanding CKD due to most causes results in bilaterally small kidneys. Causes of CKD with normal size kidneys are:

  • Diabetic nephropathy (kidney size may be increased at the onset)
  • Amyloidosis
  • HIV nephropathy

questions.text: A 65-year-old hypertensive patient has recently been diagnosed with stage 3 chronic kidney disease. According to the ESC 2018 guidelines, what target blood pressure would you choose for this patient?
questions.solution:
According to the ESC 2018 guidelines, the target blood pressure in hypertensive patients with CKD is < 140/ 80 mm Hg regardless of age.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man who has been on dialysis for 2 years presents with bone pain and bowing of legs. Further evaluation reveals hyperparathyroidism and hyperphosphatemia. What is the initial treatment of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of secondary hyperparathyroidism (HPT) and hyperphosphatemia in a patient with CKD. Sevelamer is the best initial treatment for this patient. It is a phosphate binder that reduces the absorption of phosphate from the gastrointestinal tract.

Other phosphate binders that can be used include:

  • Calcium containing
    • Calcium acetate
    • Calcium carbonate
  • Non-calcium containing
    • Sevelamer
    • Lanthanum

Calcitriol and cinacalcet are used to decrease PTH levels in secondary hyperparathyroidism. However, they also cause increased serum phosphate levels. Hence, they should not be given as initial treatment in patients with hyperphosphatemia.

Bisphosphonates like pamidronate are used in the treatment of primary hyperparathyroidism.

World Kidney Day is a global health event celebrated annually on the 2nd Thursday in March since 2006. This year, on March 14, the theme is "Kidney Health for All: Advancing equitable access to care and optimal medication practice." The focus is on overcoming barriers like gaps in early diagnosis, limited healthcare coverage, low awareness among healthcare workers, and challenges in medication accessibility and cost. The goal is to promote awareness about the vital role of kidneys and address issues to ensure optimal kidney care worldwide.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate definitive treatment for anemia in patients with chronic kidney disease?
questions.solution:
Anemia in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) is primarily due to decreased erythropoietin production. Hence, human recombinant erythropoietin (EPO) such as darbepoetin is the most appropriate treatment and is considered the mainstay.

However, an optimal response to treatment with EPO occurs only when iron stores are adequate. Hence, iron supplements (oral or IV) must be given first to ensure the effectiveness of EPO therapy. 

Other treatment options for anemia in CKD are:

  • Vitamin B12 and folate supplementation
  • Blood transfusion - in severe anemia and failure to EPO therapy

The FDA recently apporved Daprodustat as the first oral treatment for anemia caused by CKD for adults who have been receiving dialysis for at least four months. The drug acts by increasing erythropoietin levels.

questions.text: Which of the following should not be used in a patient with CKD?
questions.solution:
Diclofenac should not be used in a patient with CKD as it is nephrotoxic.

Renal blood flow is regulated by prostaglandin E2. Aspirin, diclofenac and other NSAIDs inhibit cyclooxygenase. This decreases prostaglandin E2 concentration, thereby causing a reduction in blood flow and GFR. 

Nephrotoxic drugs include the following:

  • NSAIDs
  • Antifungals (amphotericin B)
  • Antibiotics
    • Aminoglycosides
    • Vancomycin
    • Cephalosporins
    • Sulfonamides
    • Streptomycin
  • Antivirals
    • Acyclovir
    • Foscarnet
  • Chemotherapy drugs
    • Methotrexate
    • Platins
  • Immunosuppressants (cyclosporine)

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with type 2 diabetes has developed stage 4 CKD secondary to diabetic nephropathy.  He currently takes insulin for his diabetes. What changes need to be made to his regimen?
questions.solution:
In CKD patients with diabetes, the dose of insulin must be reduced.

In CKD patients, the plasma levels of insulin are elevated due to diminished renal degradation of insulin by the impaired kidney. This impaired renal clearance of insulin can lead to hypoglycemia. Hence, the dose of insulin must be reduced to prevent this.
